fxInfo_clarification: A means-tested program targets poor, needy, or otherwise underprivileged constituents. Cash-transfer programs are normally means-tested. A universal (non-means tested) program potentially benefits everyone. This includes free education, national health care schemes, and retirement programs. Granted, some may benefit more than others from these programs (e.g., when people with higher salaries get higher unemployment benefits). The key point is that practically everyone is a beneficiary, or potential beneficiary. The purpose of this question is not to gauge the size of the welfare state but rather its quality. So, your answer should be based on whatever programs exist.
fxInfo_cross_coder_aggregation: Bayesian Item Response Theory Measurement Model
fxInfo_question: How many welfare programs are means-tested and how many benefit all (or virtually all) members of the polity?

fxInfo_responses.value: There are no, or extremely limited, welfare state policies (education, health, retirement, unemployment, poverty programs).
Almost all of the welfare state policies are means-tested.
Most welfare state policies means-tested, but a significant portion (e.g. 1/4 or 1/3) is universalistic and potentially benefits everyone in the population.
The welfare state policies are roughly evenly divided between means-tested and universalistic.
Most welfare state policies are universalistic, but a significant portion (e.g., 1/4 or 1/3) are means-tested.
Almost all welfare state policies are universal in character. Only a small portion is meanstested.

fxInfo_scale: Ordinal, converted to interval by the measurement model
